title: Dwiggins Book recommendation needed
content: Can anyone recommend the "must-have" book by [Dwiggins](http://web.archive.org/web/20131106101259/http:/typophile.com/wiki/William%20Addison%20Dwiggins)?
author: Prakash Nair

comments.content:
All of them.

or the best collected writings: MSS by WAD
I doubt you could get closer to Dwiggins' heart than The Dwiggins Marionettes.

I am surprised that our resident Dwiggins devotee Miss Tiffany has not yet chimed in.

ChrisL

I have to agree with Rich, all of them is the best answer. There is a book, soon to be released, about Dwiggins' life which will be a must have. The MSS are good. WAD to RR is really good, an excellent (and historical) "primer" for type designers. I'm a collector though. So maybe my thoughts are warped.

Tiff,  
What is WAD to RR? Some of us don't know the code.

ChrisL

Dwiggins, William Addison, WAD to RR (Rudulph Ruzick) a letter about designing type. Cambridge, MA: Harvard College Library, 1940.

[http://www.cs.ru.nl/~freek/books/wadtorr.sat](http://web.archive.org/web/20131106101259/http:/www.cs.ru.nl/~freek/books/wadtorr.sat "http://www.cs.ru.nl/~freek/books/wadtorr.sat")

Thank you Vincent!--and I do love your business card even with all its faults :-)

ChrisL
you still making business card cracks, chris? \>^P

But you are not ay Paul? :-)

ChrisL

_There is a book, soon to be released, about Dwiggins’ life which will be a must have._

Who, what, where? And please stop telling people to get "all." There won't be enough for the rest of us.

George  
I felt bad because I had no shoes, until I met a man who had no Bodoni

Tiff:<cite> The MSS are good. WAD to RR is really good, an excellent (and historical) “primer” for type designers.</cite>

**It also contains one of my favorite typographic quotes;  
<cite> Curves do all kinds of queer things when reduced.</cite>**

ƒ

George, I'm pretty sure the "official" announcement will be out by TypeCon of this year. The book which Dorothy Abbe put together about stencils, which I purchased from Emigre a billion years ago, is a great way to observe his use of black and white.

Oak Knoll has a few juicy items right now. [Search for WAD](http://web.archive.org/web/20131106101259/http:/www.oakknoll.com/results.php?s_ShowPics=1&search_val=WAD&search_fld=All&x=0&y=0).

For anyone collecting Dwiggins, the best reference is Dwight Agner's _The Books of WAD_ which lists everything he designed.

George
